code: par(mfrow=c(2,2)) par(mar=c(2,2,2,2))  # bottom, left, top, right  hist(out_kitt$allbirds_prey_sim, breaks=50, col=gray(0.6), main="Kittiwake") lines(rep(out_kitt$allbirds_prey_est,2),c(0,10000),lwd=2)  hist(out_cogu$allbirds_prey_sim, breaks=50, col=gray(0.6), main="Guillemot") lines(rep(out_cogu$allbirds_prey_est,2),c(0,10000),lwd=2)  hist(out_razo$allbirds_prey_sim, breaks=50, col=gray(0.6), main="Razorbill") lines(rep(out_razo$allbirds_prey_est,2),c(0,10000),lwd=2)

code: dev.off() #> null device  #>           1 tab_kitt <- data.frame(   Species = "Kittiwake",   Estimate = out_kitt$allbirds_prey_est,    Sim_CI_Lower = as.numeric(quantile(out_kitt$allbirds_prey_sim, 0.025)),    Sim_Mean = mean(out_kitt$allbirds_prey_sim),    Sim_CI_Upper = as.numeric(quantile(out_kitt$allbirds_prey_sim, 0.975)))  tab_cogu <- data.frame(   Species = "Guillemot",   Estimate = out_cogu$allbirds_prey_est,    Sim_CI_Lower = as.numeric(quantile(out_cogu$allbirds_prey_sim, 0.025)),    Sim_Mean = mean(out_cogu$allbirds_prey_sim),    Sim_CI_Upper = as.numeric(quantile(out_cogu$allbirds_prey_sim, 0.975)))  tab_razo <- data.frame(   Species = "Razorbill",   Estimate = out_razo$allbirds_prey_est,    Sim_CI_Lower = as.numeric(quantile(out_razo$allbirds_prey_sim, 0.025)),    Sim_Mean = mean(out_razo$allbirds_prey_sim),    Sim_CI_Upper = as.numeric(quantile(out_razo$allbirds_prey_sim, 0.975)))  kable(rbind(tab_kitt, tab_cogu, tab_razo))

what: Footprints smaller than one grid cell
title: Worked example
code: fppolys <- sf::st_read(system.file("demo/North_Sea_OWF_2030_polygons", package = "spmapper")) #> Reading layer `North_Sea_OWF_2030_polygons' from data source  #>   `C:\Users\clacap\AppData\Local\Temp\RtmpmIU3Cj\temp_libpath2028cd3641\spmapper\demo\North_Sea_OWF_2030_polygons'  #>   using driver `ESRI Shapefile' #> Simple feature collection with 177 features and 4 fields #> Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON #> Dimension:     XY #> Bounding box:  xmin: -269946.2 ymin: -4249826 xmax: 697913.1 ymax: -3159479 #> Projected CRS: North_Pole_Lambert_Azimuthal_Equal_Area fppolys <- fppolys[which.min(sf::st_area(fppolys)),]  spmapper(spname = "Kittiwake", fppolys = fppolys, popscen = "baseline", tooldir = tooldir) #> Error in fpudoverlap(fppolys = fppolys, udmap = udmap): Size of footprint is smaller than the size of a single grid cell - tool would not produce meaningful results in this situation

(2025) “Time-activity budgets energetics common guillemot, razorbill, Atlantic puffin, black-legged kittiwake”, NERC EDS Environmental Information Data Centre. doi: 10.5285/07b1105a-4a14-47e3-b491-9af59be90aff. Wakefield, E. D., Owen, E., Baer, J., Carroll, M. J., Daunt, F., Dodd, S. G., Green, J. ., Guilford, T., Mavor, R. ., Miller, P. ., Newell, M. ., Newton, S. F., Robertson, G. S., Shoji, ., Soanes, L. M., Votier, S. C., Wanless, S. Bolton, M. (2017) “Breeding density, fine-scale tracking, large-scale modeling reveal regional distribution four seabird species.,” Ecological Applications, 27(7), pp. 2074–2091. doi: 10.1002/eap.1591.

title: spmapper
text: Offshore wind energy central UK’s renewable energy strategy projected expand substantially terms generation capacity, number area coverage offshore windfarms (OWFs). OWFs potential adverse impacts marine wildlife, including seabirds, travel forage offshore areas. Among possible impact mechanisms, OWFs may impact seabirds via displacement foraging habitat, , seabirds may avoid windfarms areas might otherwise forage. , displacement windfarms may correspond loss access prey foraging seabirds. breeding season—particular period breeding adults rearing chicks—energetically demanding time seabirds. Seabirds must acquire sufficient prey sustain energetic requirements, provisioning chicks fledging. Breeding outcomes important seabird population dynamics long-term resilience. —seabirds must forage areas centred breeding colony—impacts OWFs breeding season critical seabird conservation. possible observe foraging success sufficient scales empirically map seabird prey consumption, describe energetic value marine areas specific seabird species. address , developed spmapper, spatial planning tool indicate foraging value marine areas key seabird species breed coasts islands UK (Black-legged Kittiwake Rissa tridactyla, Common guillemot Uria aalge, Razorbill Alca torda). spmapper underpinned seabird time-activity budget energetics data collated Black-legged kittiwake Rissa tridactyla, Common guillemot Uria aalge, Razorbill Alca torda, published via NERC Environmental Information Data Centre (Leedham et al. 2025). spmapper written programming language R (R Core Team, 2017). Information cite spmapper included ‘cite’ section.

title: spmapper
text: spmapper spatial planning tool generates maps seabird prey consumption chick-rearing seabirds. tool generates maps calculating mass fish prey taken seabird species network according species-specific behaviour, physiology, diet, demography population size; estimates spatial origin seabird prey removal according models marine space use (utilisation distributions, UDs). See ‘Methods’ page details. [Define population interest].<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<< central function spmapper retrieve estimates absolute proportional quantities prey taken focal species within areas interest user. words, aim tool indicate energetic foraging value marine areas seabirds terms prey consumption shelf-seas scale. primary applications outputs include comparison total prey consumption candidate areas offshore renewable developments, within areas protective conservation measures. […assist marine spatial planning]<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<

what: Function to calculate prey intake (kg) for one or more adults — fn.tot.prey
title: Function to calculate prey intake (kg) for one or more adults — fn.tot.prey
text: fn.tot.prey represents model calculates intake prey (kg) single breeding adult seabird across duration chick rearing, based set values describing physiology, ecology demography.

title: Function to calculate prey intake (kg) for one or more adults — fn.tot.prey
code: fn.tot.prey(   TB_foraging,   TB_flying,   TB_resting_sea,   TB_nest,   ER_foraging,   ER_flying,   ER_resting_sea,   ER_nest,   ER_warming_food,   chick_ER,   chicks_n,   BS_length,   init_mass,   mass_change,   tissue_en_dens,   energy_prey_conv,   assim_effic )

title: Function to calculate prey intake (kg) for one or more adults — fn.tot.prey
text: TB_foraging Time budget: foraging: % daily time-activity budget spent foraging     (unit: % time) TB_flying Time budget: flying: % daily time-activity budget spent flying    (unit: % time) TB_resting_sea Time budget: rest sea:    % daily time-activity budget spent resting sea    (unit:     % time) TB_nest Time budget: nest:    % daily time-activity budget spent nest    (unit:     % time) ER_foraging Energy requirements: foraging:     Energetic cost full day (24h) foraging    (unit:     kj/day) ER_flying Energy requirements: flying:    Energetic cost full day (24h) flying    (unit:     kj/day) ER_resting_sea Energy requirements: rest sea:    Energetic cost full day (24h) resting sea    (unit:     kj/day) ER_nest Energy requirements: nest:    Energetic cost full day (24h) nest    (unit:     kj/day) ER_warming_food Energy requirements: warming food:    Nominal energetic cost warming food per day    (unit:     kj/day) chick_ER Energy requirements: chick provisioning:    Daily energy needs chicks (.e. provisioned parent birds)    (unit:     kj/day) chicks_n Chicks per nest (breeding success):    Chicks fledged per nest, give seasonal chick provisioning requirements    (unit:     n) BS_length Chick-rearing duration: Duration chick rearing    (unit: days) init_mass Adult body mass:    Mass typical breeding adult    (unit:     g) mass_change Percent adult mass change:    Percentage change adult body mass breeding season    (unit:     % change) tissue_en_dens Adult tissue energy density    Energy density seabird body tissue (adult)    (unit:     kj/g) energy_prey_conv Prey energy density    Energy density prey diet, used convert energy intake prey mass    (unit:     kj/g) assim_effic Digestive assimilation efficiency    Proportion dietary prey energy assimilated adult seabirds    (unit:     proportion)

title: Function to calculate prey intake (kg) for one or more adults — fn.tot.prey
text: prey intake (kg) single breeding adult seabird duration chick-rearing; argument single numeric value output also single numeric value, arguments vectors vector length length input vector

title: Function to calculate prey intake (kg) for one or more adults — fn.tot.prey
text: function first calculates daily energy requirements adult seabird, sum : ) weighted average energetic costs core 4 activities (foraging, flight, resting sea, resting colony), according time relative daily time-budget allocation. ii) cost warming daily food load iii) adult's half share chick provisioning requirements, multiplied average number chicks per nest (breeding success) Daily energy requirements scaled duration chick-rearing. Next, energy intake corrected account energy sourced via metabolism body tissue (thus prey consumption; indicated adult body mass change seabird tissue energy density). Total energy energy intake converted prey mass intake according dietary prey energy density, correcting imperfect digestive assimilation. Note, species explicitly specified function, rather function applied set parameter values corresponding given species. Note: argument can either single numeric value vector, vector vectors must length

title: Seabirds Energetics Parameters — Seabird_energetics_pars_spmapper
text: Published dataset: Leedham, O.; Searle, K.R.; Harris, M.P.; Newell, M.; Wanless, S.; Mobbs, D.C.; Butler, .; Daunt, F. (2025). Time-activity budgets energetics common guillemot, razorbill, Atlantic puffin, black-legged kittiwake. NERC EDS Environmental Information Data Centre. https://doi.org/10.5285/07b1105a-4a14-47e3-b491-9af59be90aff

what: TO BE ADDED - TITLE OF MAIN SPMAPPER FUNCTION — spmapper
title: TO BE ADDED - TITLE OF MAIN SPMAPPER FUNCTION — spmapper
text: ADDED - OVERALL DESCRIPTION SPMAPPER

title: TO BE ADDED - TITLE OF MAIN SPMAPPER FUNCTION — spmapper
code: spmapper(spname, fppolys, popscen, tooldir)

title: TO BE ADDED - TITLE OF MAIN SPMAPPER FUNCTION — spmapper
text: spname Species name: character string. Must "Guillemot", "Kittiwake" "Razorbill" fppolys Footprint(s): simple feature collection popscen Population scenario: character string. Must "baseline", "low" "high" tooldir Path directory containing tool: character string.

title: TO BE ADDED - TITLE OF MAIN SPMAPPER FUNCTION — spmapper
text: list, elements: "spname" (species name), "popscen" (population scenario"), "energypars_base_est" (energetics parameters - estimates), "energypars_base_sim" (energetics parameters - simulations), "udmap" (utilisation distribution, raster), "popsize" (population size - BREEDING PAIRS TBC, "fp_ud_overlap" (proportion UD within footprint), "nbirds_in_fp" (number birds footprints), "onebird_prey_kg_est" (prey intake one bird - estimate), "onebird_prey_kg_sim" (prey intake one bird - simulations), "allbirds_prey_est" (prey intake birds footprints - estimate), "allbirds_prey_sim" (prey intake birds footprints - simulations)

what: Plot prey consumption maps, with user polygons overlaid (optional) — spmapplot
title: Plot prey consumption maps, with user polygons overlaid (optional) — spmapplot
text: Plot prey consumption maps, user polygons overlaid (optional)

title: Plot prey consumption maps, with user polygons overlaid (optional) — spmapplot
code: spmapplot(rast, polyg = NULL)

title: Plot prey consumption maps, with user polygons overlaid (optional) — spmapplot
text: rast spatRaster raster object plotted (.e. prey consumption map) polyg optional sf object (.e. user polygons) overlay raster plot (default: NULL).

title: Plot prey consumption maps, with user polygons overlaid (optional) — spmapplot
text: Prey consumption map Western European country polygons (via rnaturalearth), (optional) user input polygons overlaid: ggplot
